title: 2020 Six Nations Championship squads
text:
This is a list of the complete squads for the <a href="2020%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2020 Six Nations Championship</a>, an annual <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> tournament contested by the national rugby teams of <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>, <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">France</a>, <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland</a>, <a href="Italy%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy</a>, <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> and <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a>. Wales are the defending champions.
Note: Number of caps and players' ages are indicated as of 1 February 2020 – the tournament's opening day. For players added to a squad during the tournament, their caps and age are indicated as of the date of their call-up.
England.
On 20 January, Eddie Jones named a 36-man squad for the <a href="2020%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2020 Six Nations Championship</a>. In February 2020 it was announced that <a href="Beno%20Obano">Beno Obano</a> and <a href="Henry%20Slade">Henry Slade</a> had joined the squad with <a href="Mako%20Vunipola">Mako Vunipola</a> withdrawing for family reasons. 
Head coach: <a href="Eddie%20Jones%20%28rugby%20union%29">Eddie Jones</a>
France.
On 8 January, Galthié named a 42-man squad for the <a href="2020%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2020 Six Nations Championship</a>.
Head coach: <a href="Fabien%20Galthi%C3%A9">Fabien Galthié</a>
Call-ups<br>
On 13 January, <a href="Peato%20Mauvaka">Peato Mauvaka</a> was called up to replace the injured <a href="Anthony%20%C3%89trillard">Anthony Étrillard</a>.
On 19 January, <a href="Wilfrid%20Hounkpatin">Wilfrid Hounkpatin</a> was called up to replace the injured <a href="Dorian%20Aldegheri">Dorian Aldegheri</a>.
On 26 January, Alexandre Roumat and Yvan Reilhac were called up to replace the injured Dylan Cretin and Kylan Hamdaoui.
On 27 January, Teddy Baubigny was called up to replace the injured Camille Chat.
On 17 February: Guillaume Ducat, Maxime Lucu, Baptiste Delaporte, Alivereti Raka & Lucas Tauzin were called up to replace the injured Cyril Cazeaux, Baptiste Couilloud, Sekou Makalou, Julien Hériteau & Lester Etien.
Ireland.
On 15 January 2020, <a href="Andy%20Farrell">Andy Farrell</a> named his 35-man Ireland squad for the <a href="2020%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2020 Six Nations Championship</a>.
Head coach: <a href="Andy%20Farrell">Andy Farrell</a>
Call-ups<br>
On 20 January, <a href="Stuart%20McCloskey">Stuart McCloskey</a> was added to the squad due to a number of backs sustaining minor knocks.
On 3 February, <a href="Will%20Connors">Will Connors</a> was added to the squad.
Italy.
On 19 January 2020, Italy named their 36-man squad for the <a href="2020%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2020 Six Nations Championship</a>. <br>
On 20 January 2020, Giovanni Pettinelli replaces David Sisi.
Head Coach: <a href="Franco%20Smith">Franco Smith</a> (interim)
Scotland.
On 15 January 2020, Townsend named a 38-man squad.
Head coach: <a href="Gregor%20Townsend">Gregor Townsend</a>
Call-ups
On 24 January Duncan Weir was called up to join the squad.
On 16 February Sam Skinner and Matt Fagerson were added to the squad, with Alex Craig being released back to his club.
On 1 March Lewis Carmichael was added to the squad, with Cornell du Preez being released back to his club.
Wales.
On 15 January 2020, Pivac announced a 38-man squad.
Head coach: <a href="Wayne%20Pivac">Wayne Pivac</a>
